it is a rapidly rising residential 
suburb, known for its ouzo and 
fish tavernas.
MUST SEE:
Gallikos River.
It stretches along Kalochori’s 
west edge. The municipality 
has set up kiosks and facilities 
so that travellers can stop over, 
relax or go picnicking along 
the riverside. Further south 
you will see the river delta and 
Kalochori lagoon with herons, 
pelicans, flamingoes and water 
buffaloes. A further while 
towards the west (beyond the 
city limits), you will see the 
wetland of the Delta formed 
by the rivers Axios, Loudias 
and Aliakmonas. This is a 320 
km2 area, protected by the 
Ramsar Convention [a.k.a. The 
Convention on Wetlands of 
International Importance] and 
is also included in the Natura 
2000 network. The Axios – 
Loudias – Aliakmonas Estuaries 
Management Authority offers 
free tours in the area (www.
axiosdelta.gr).
1.1  Sindos.
It is located approx.', '66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.
MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).', '99
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc).', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.']

response:
Suburbs and urban areas have distinct characteristics. Suburbs typically have a more relaxed atmosphere, with less commercial and entertainment activity compared to urban areas. Suburbs often have a mix of residential, commercial, and industrial areas, but with a greater emphasis on residential living. They usually have easier access to nature and outdoor spaces. Suburbs often have a slower pace of life, with fewer people and less noise pollution.

In contrast, urban areas are more densely populated, have more commercial and entertainment activity, and a faster pace of life. Urban areas often have a greater variety of cultural, historical, and entertainment attractions. They usually have more public transportation options and a wider range of dining and shopping options. Urban areas can be more challenging to navigate, with more traffic and congestion.

In the context of Thessaloniki, suburbs like Kalochori, Kalamaria, and Chortiatis offer a more relaxed atmosphere, with easy access to nature and outdoor spaces. They provide a mix of residential, commercial, and industrial areas, and have a slower pace of life. Suburbs like Chortiatis also offer opportunities for hiking, mountain biking, and off-roading, making them attractive for outdoor enthusiasts.

Overall, suburbs in Thessaloniki offer a more laid-back and natural environment, with easier access to outdoor spaces and a slower pace of life. They provide a unique experience for those seeking a more relaxed and peaceful atmosphere, while still being within easy reach of the city's attractions and amenities.
reference: Suburbs are typically characterized by lower population density, residential areas, and more green spaces compared to urban areas, which are more densely populated and have a higher concentration of commercial and industrial activities.

['93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.', '10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', 'Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', '37
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
1970. It combines elements 
of modern and traditional 
Macedonian architecture with

1.9  Acheiropoiitos church.
(see p. 9) 
1.10 Agios [Saint] 
Athanasios church.
This timber-roofed church  
is located in the SE side  
of Acheiropoiitos church.  
It was built in 1818 as a three-
aisled basilica and until 1880 
there were ruins of an ancient 
structure in the churchyard.  
It is now a parish church.
1.11 Nedelkou Building.
(109, Egnatia st.). This 1909 
building is a two-storeyed 
piece of fine architecture (Xen. 
Paionidis). In the past, the 
ground floor housed shops 
and the 1st floor was the 
house of the Nedelkou family. 
It combines renaissance, 
baroque, neoclassical and art-
nouveau elements and has an 
interesting interior decoration. 
Today it houses the Mount 
Athos Centre where the stay 
permits are issued to those 
who wish to visit the Mount 
Athos monasteries (see p. 92); 
there is also a bookshop and 
an exhibition area.
1.12 Galerius Arch (Kamara).
One of the town’s major 
landmarks, this arch is  
the usual rendezvous place  
for locals.', '91
DAY EXCURSIONS
Praetorium and the public 
toilets (called Vespasians) 
which were located to the east.
The Hydraulis sector.
This was a complex of 
buildings named after the 
copper hydraulis [a type of pipe 
organ] found here along with 
a multitude of other copper 
items.
Villa of Dionysus.
This urban area house (2nd c.  
AD) is where an amazing mosaic  
was found, depicting Dionysus 
on a chariot coming out  
of the sea.
Archaeological Museum.
Housed in a brand new 
building, the Archaeological 
Museum showcases finds 
from the Dion area (statues, 
inscriptions, artefacts 
etc) classified in thematic 
groups (public buildings, 
houses, sanctuaries, ancient 
technology etc), and also finds 
from the foot of Mt Olympus 
and ancient Pydna. The Ancient 
Relics House lies opposite and 
showcases more recent finds 
from ongoing excavations.
3.1  Mt. Olympus.
The highest Greek mountain 
(2,918 m.) is globally known  
as the residence of the 12 gods 
of ancient Greek mythology. 
It is the first National Park of 
Greece (1938); in 1981 it was 
designated a World Biosphere 
Reserve area by UNESCO.']

5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf

and Volvi; the place is a

MUST SEE:
5.1  Lagadas.
This picturesque town 
is situated 20 km NE of 
Thessaloniki and has been 
known for keeping the custom 
of fire-walking (anastenaria) 
on May 21st. The ultra modern 
Spa facilities of the area also 
include two Byzantine bathtubs 
(10th and 15th c.) and they 
are located two km E amid 
lush greenery. The sulphur 
springs (water temperature: 
39.2ο C) are recommended 
for treating neuropathy, 
rheumatism, arthritis, skin and 
gynaecological diseases.

response: The criteria that led to Mount Athos being designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site are its outstanding architecture and the priceless cultural treasures of the monastic community. Specifically, the monastic state of Mount Athos encompasses 20 presently inhabited monasteries, sketes, and cells for monks, showcasing a unique and historic collection of Byzantine architecture and art. The UNESCO designation recognizes the cultural and historical significance of Mount Athos, acknowledging its importance as a center of Byzantine Christianity and its role in preserving the traditions and artifacts of the monastic community. The site's designation as a World Heritage Monument is a testament to its enduring cultural and historical importance, and it serves as a valuable resource for future generations to learn from and appreciate.
reference: Mount Athos was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1988 due to its outstanding architecture and priceless cultural treasures of the monastic community.

where there are playgrounds 
Thessaloniki Wines. 
Macedonia has a long 
tradition on wine-making, 
as the district can boast 
some of the most renowned 
Greek vineyards. In the area 
surrounding the town, a wide 
range of varieties are grown 
such as Roditis, Asyrtiko,

Rouge, Limnio, Mavroudi,

Association of Northern 
Greece Vineyards, under the

Greece, realises a programme

6th walk: 
NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE
1.5  Theme gardens.
Along Megalou Alexandrou 
Avenue towards the direction 
of the sea, 12 Theme Gardens 
cover an area of 76,657 m2

and a skatepark); and Garden of

music events. You can also ride 
along the area’s 3 km cycle path. 
This is also the location of the 
Nautical Club of Thessaloniki.
1.6  Thessaloniki Concert 
Hall.
It was inaugurated in 2000 on 
a privileged location.', '79
MUSEUMS
from amateur stations in 
town. Photographic material 
and voice archives comprising 
extracts from speeches of 
major personalities in the 
Modern Greek history are also 
on display. 
WATER MUSEUM
The museum is housed in 
three restored buildings and 
the surrounding grounds, 
covering a total area of 3,000 
m2. The main building (pump 
room) contains pumping 
machinery, motors and 
power-generating machines, 
old power distribution panels 
and a piece of steam-driven 
machinery, in the multi-use 
room (old boiler-room) 
there is an impressive array 
of old steam boilers; in the 
management building there 
is a library with specialised 
volumes on water and hydraulic 
works as well as an archive of 
rare historical maps, old water-
supply plans and photographs. 
In the Water Park there are 
old pumping machinery and 
pipelines on display.
CHILDREN’S MUSEUM
This multi-theme museum 
opened in 1997 and it was 
housed in a traditional building  
in Ano Poli quarter (see p. 47),  
until 2009 when it was destroyed

in the Cultural Centre of the

and targets the 4-12 age group,

on games, entertainment and

NOESIS SCIENCE CENTRE 
AND TECHNOLOGY

7th walk: 
WEST OF THE CENTRE-STAVROUPOLI
3.2  Mylos multi purpose 
venue.
It is housed in the premises 
of the old Flour Mill [Mylos 
in Greek] of Chatzigiannaki-
Altinalmazi (1924). In 1991 
it passed to private owners 
and was changed into a 
culture venue that is well-
known throughout the country. 
The biggest names of the 
domestic and international 
music scene have chosen to 
appear here; the cafés, bars 
and restaurants found in the 
complex are very popular with 
Thessalonians. 
3.3  FIX Brewery.
The brewery was founded 
in 1893 by Misrachi and 
Fernandez. Later on, annexes 
were added to the original 
installations and the firms 
Olympus Brewery and Olympus-
Naoussa Brewery were 
successively set up. In 1926 
FIX company took and retained 
ownership of the brewery until 
the mid-1980’s when it was 
closed down. Today the place 
is deserted with the exception 
of certain newer storehouses 
which were restructured into 
concert halls. Since 2001, the 
Water Museum (see p. 79) is 
housed in the adjacent old main 
pumping station of the Water 
Company (1890-94), which was 
running until 1978.', '39
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
Museum houses exhibits  
of human skulls, known 
worldwide to have been found 
in the area of Axios river 
(aged 9.5 million years) and 
in the Petralona Cave (see p. 
92), aged approx. 200,000 –

places are the Biblical, 
Folk Art, and Criminology

Modern Greek literature and

One of the finest buildings

3 	\x07
AGIOU DIMITRIOU 
STREET
This large road in the

a beautiful block of flats

3 	ELEFTHERIAS SQUARE
The square is close to the

is the spot where, back in

response:
Oktovriou St. is the street where the Water Museum is located. The significance of Oktovriou St. lies in its connection to the Water Museum, which is housed in the adjacent old main pumping station of the Water Company. The pumping station was running from 1890-94 and was closed until 1978. Today, the Water Museum occupies the site, providing insight into the city's water management history. Visitors can explore the museum's exhibits, which include pumping machinery, old steam boilers, and other historical artifacts related to the water supply system. The location of the Water Museum on Oktovriou St. offers a unique opportunity for tourists to learn about Thessaloniki's water management past and its significance in the city's development. 

It's worth noting that Oktovriou St. is also notable for being the location of the old Flour Mill, which has been converted into a cultural venue known as Mylos. This venue hosts various events, including music performances, and is a popular spot for locals and tourists alike. The area surrounding Oktovriou St. is also home to several other notable landmarks, including the historic centre and the Agios Dimitriou Street, which offer a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich history and cultural heritage. 

Overall, Oktovriou St. is an important location in Thessaloniki, not only because of its connection to the Water Museum but also due to its rich cultural and historical significance. Visitors to the city can explore the area, take in the sights and sounds, and experience the unique character of Oktovriou St. for themselves.
reference: Oktovriou St. is significant as it is the location of the Water Museum, specifically at 19, 26th Oktovriou St.

user_input: What activities can visitors enjoy at the mountain refuge located on Mt Chortiatis?
retrieved_contexts:
['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', 'Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.
3 	PANORAMA
One of the best suburbs of 
Thessaloniki is situated at  
a 12 km distance S of the 
city centre and was built on 
the slope of Mt Chortiatis, 
offering a panoramic city view. 
It was uninhabited until the 
early 20th c., although traces 
of a prehistoric settlement 
have been located on the area. 
The first inhabitants were 
refugees from Asia Minor and 
Pontus. Today its largest part 
is covered by luxury villas and 
impressive detached homes; 
there is a small shopping 
area in the centre. Trigona 
Panoramatos [a cream puff 
pastry] – one of the city’s best 
known sweet delicacies – were 
created at a local confectionery 
in the 1950’s.
MUST SEE:
Platanakia.
It is a nice place for relaxing, 
in a wooded ravine, with a 
small Zoo and a café. A 6 km 
path begins here and leads 
up to the artificial lake (dam) 
of Thermi. Along the way you 
will come across spots for a 
brief rest, short waterfalls and 
fragments of eight Byzantine 
watermills.', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.', '101
and sports facilities.
Tour the suburban forests 
of Seich Sou (see p. 47) and 
Chortiatis (see p. 66) where 
you can follow the hiking trails 
or go mountain biking, find the 
spots designated for sports 
activities or just relax by the 
Deltas of Gallikos river and 
Axios-Loudias-Aliakmonas 
rivers (see p. 63) or by the 
lakes Koroneia and Volvi  
(see p. 93-94).
There are some quite 
interesting educational 
programmes for children, 
running in most museums 
(see p. 70 - 81), particularly 
in the Children’s Museum 
(see p. 79) which is the only one  
of its kind.
Have fun and at the same  
time get familiar with science  
and technology at the Noesis  
– Science Centre and 
Technology Museum (see p. 
67) or at the Nouvelle multi-
purpose venue (7th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Oraiokastro 
Road) where you can visit the 
Environmental Dinosaur Theme 
Park and see the natural size 
reconstructions of animals, 
the Mammoth Museum where 
fossils of the hairy mammoth 
are on display, the Cave where 
there are depictions of creation 
and prehistoric life in caves  
as well as the Interactive 
Museum of Greek Traditional 
Toys and Games  
(www.parkodeinosauron.gr).   
Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p.', 'It is a rare 
group of ecosystems with wet 
forests and meadows, rivers 
and shrubland, and the ideal 
place for outdoor activities 
(horse-riding, mountain biking, 
birdwatching, agritourism 
and so on); the Agency for 
the Management of Lakes 
Koroneia and Volvi (www.
foreaskv.gr) runs tours in 
the area. Make sure you try 
some of the local delicacies, 
including lake fish dishes.
MUST SEE:
5.1  Lagadas.
This picturesque town 
is situated 20 km NE of 
Thessaloniki and has been 
known for keeping the custom 
of fire-walking (anastenaria) 
on May 21st. The ultra modern 
Spa facilities of the area also 
include two Byzantine bathtubs 
(10th and 15th c.) and they 
are located two km E amid 
lush greenery. The sulphur 
springs (water temperature: 
39.2ο C) are recommended 
for treating neuropathy, 
rheumatism, arthritis, skin and 
gynaecological diseases.
111']

response:
Visitors can enjoy various activities at the mountain refuge located on Mt Chortiatis. These include hiking, mountain biking, and off-roading. The refuge offers 32 charted paths, allowing visitors to explore the beautiful scenery and natural surroundings. Additionally, the mountain refuge is situated in a wooded ravine, providing a peaceful and serene atmosphere. Visitors can also relax by the nearby Deltas of Gallikos river and Axios-Loudias-Aliakmonas rivers. For those interested in exploring the local culture, the mountain refuge is close to the Petralona Cave, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 

Furthermore, visitors can also explore the nearby lakes Koroneia and Volvi, which offer a range of outdoor activities such as birdwatching, agritourism, and horse-riding. The Agency for the Management of Lakes Koroneia and Volvi runs guided tours in the area, providing visitors with a unique and educational experience. 

For those looking for a more leisurely experience, the mountain refuge offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape, making it an ideal spot for photography. The refuge is also close to the picturesque town of Lagadas, which offers a range of local delicacies and traditional experiences. 

Overall, the mountain refuge on Mt Chortiatis offers a unique blend of outdoor activities, cultural experiences, and natural beauty, making it an ideal destination for visitors looking to explore the natural wonders of the area.
reference: Visitors at the mountain refuge on Mt Chortiatis can enjoy activities such as hiking on 32 charted paths, mountain biking, and off-roading.

user_input: What architectural features define a cross-in-square domed church, as exemplified by the Moni Latomou?
retrieved_contexts:
['15
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The 
small picturesque yard offers 
an unobstructed view of the 
city and the Thermaic gulf.
13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community.', '42) is 
thought to have been the 
main church of Nea Moni [New 
Monastery] or Moni Akapniou 
[Akapniou Monastery]. It was 
situated in the area of the 
Byzantine palaces and this 
is why the Turks had named 
the area Balat (Palace) and 
the church Eski Saray Camii 
(Old Palace mosque). It is a 
tetrastyle cross-in-square 
domed church with features 
related to the monasterial 
architecture of Mount Athos. 
The central dome is supported 
by granite columns in the 
shape of a cross, the building’s 
central part was enlarged by 
the addition of two conchs 
[semi-domes] whereas in 
the west section there is a 
rectangular cupolaed narthex. 
The murals (14th c.) depict 
images of saints and scenes 
from the life and miracles of 
Christ. Also, at the junction of 
Olympiados and Amfilochias 
Sts. there is a surviving 
ottoman fountain.
11	\x07BYZANTINE BATHS  
(KULE KAFE)
It is located on Romfei Sq. (see 
p. 43) in Ano Poli and it is the 
only surviving Byzantine bath 
house, a domed 13th c. building 
made of brick, which was 
open to the public until 1940. 
7. 
Profitis Ilias 
Church.
8. 
Moni Vlatadon 
is right in the 
heart of Upper 
(Old) City.
7', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', '14
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
9 	\x07
AGIA AIKATERINI  
[St. CATHERINE’s] 
CHURCH
This 14th c. Byzantine church is 
situated in the centre of Agia 
Aikaterini town quarter in Ano 
Poli [Upper City] area (see p. 
42) It is a complex tetrastyle 
inscribed cross-in-square 
five-domed church with an 
ambulatory. It bears an elaborate 
brick-work on the external 
surfaces and outstanding 
murals, contemporary to the 
construction of the edifice, 
which depict figures of saints, 
scenes from the Gospel, 
miracles of Christ etc. During 
the Ottoman Rule the church 
was converted into a mosque 
(Yakup Pasha Camii) and the 
murals were covered in plaster, 
to be exposed once again during 
the restoration works that took 
place in 1947 – 1951.
10	\x07PROFITIS ILIAS 
[PROPHET ELIJAH] 
CHURCH
This imposing church (late 13th 
– mid 14th c.) towering over 
Olympiados st. in the outskirts 
of Ano Poli (see p. 42) is 
thought to have been the 
main church of Nea Moni [New 
Monastery] or Moni Akapniou 
[Akapniou Monastery].', '4 	ROMFEI SQUARE
This is Ano Poli’s central 
square. To reach it, take 
Theofilou Street where 
the neoclassical building 
housing the Vice-Mayor’s 
office for Culture is located. 
In the square, you will see a 
Byzantine bath-house known 
as Koule Kafe (see p. 12); the 
entire area has been named 
after it. On the NE side of the 
square (7, Krispou st.) you 
will notice the architectural 
masterpiece of a 19th c. 
neoclassical building which 
houses the municipal Library of 
Ano Poli. On Theotokopoulou 
Street, near the square lies 
the 14th c. Byzantine church

(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The 
small picturesque yard offers 
an unobstructed view of the 
city and the Thermaic gulf.
13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community. It was 
founded in the 14th c. by the 
monks Vlatis (or Vlateus) 
brothers and was dedicated to 
Pantocrator Christos [Almighty 
Christ]. Celebrations take 
place on the Transfiguration 
of Christ feast day. Its main 
church [katholikon] is of the 
inscribed cross-in-square type 
but the dome rests on the 
walls and on two piers instead 
of columns. It is surrounded 
by a portico and there are two 
chapels. Murals were painted 
during 1360 – 1380 and the 
17th c. iconostasis is particularly 
noteworthy. It is surrounded 
by a large garden offering a 
wonderful view of the city and 
there is also a small peacock 
farm; in the grounds you will 
also find the newer buildings 
of Misirogleios Library, the 
Patriarchal Foundation for 
Theological Studies (1968),  
a space provided for the study of 
pictorial manuscripts from Mount 
Athos, a bookstore and a shop.

response:
The cross-in-square domed church is characterized by a central square plan with a cross-shaped layout. The architectural features that define this type of church include:

*   A central square: typically 10-15 meters in size, which serves as the focal point of the church
*   A cross-shaped layout: with four arms extending from the center square, each containing a nave
*   A dome: typically a hemispherical or spherical shape, which covers the central square and provides a sense of enclosure and intimacy
*   A square plan: with the arms and center square forming a symmetrical and balanced composition
*   Typically, the arms are connected by a central column or pilaster, which supports the dome

The Moni Latomou, a 5th or 6th century Byzantine church, exemplifies these features. Its central square plan, cross-shaped layout, and hemispherical dome create a striking and iconic architectural form. The use of brick and stone materials, combined with intricate mosaics and ornate decorations, further emphasizes its Byzantine heritage.

The cross-in-square domed church is a testament to the ingenuity and creativity of Byzantine architects, who developed this style to convey spiritual and symbolic meaning. The Moni Latomou, with its impressive architecture and stunning mosaics, is a prime example of this style, offering a glimpse into the rich cultural heritage of Greece. As a solo traveler, you can appreciate the beauty and significance of this church, and take Instagram-worthy photos to capture the moment.
reference: A cross-in-square domed church, as exemplified by the Moni Latomou, is defined by its early construction dating back to the 5th or 6th century, featuring a dome that rests on the walls and is surrounded by an inscribed cross layout.

response:
The Aristotle University of Thessaloniki holds significant architectural importance in Greece. As the first University Campus in Greece to be built following complete architectural plans, it is a notable landmark. The campus, covering a 50-hectare area, features several modern buildings designed by leading Greek architects, showcasing the Modernist design style. The main Administration Buildings, as well as those built for the Schools of Chemistry, Law, Theology, and Education, form a major ensemble of modern architecture. The campus's grandeur and modern design make it an impressive sight, especially during the summer season when the university's grounds are bustling with students.

The university's architecture is a testament to Greece's rich cultural heritage, influenced by the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman Rule, as well as the city's multicultural history. The campus's layout and design reflect the city's history, with the old Jewish cemetery (now demolished) serving as a precursor to the university's construction. The university's architecture has been recognized and celebrated, making it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and architecture.

For a solo traveler, the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki offers a unique and Instagrammable experience, with its grand buildings, modern design, and lush green surroundings. Visitors can explore the campus, take in the sights, and learn about the university's history and significance. The university's architecture is not only aesthetically pleasing but also steeped in cultural and historical significance, making it an unforgettable experience for any traveler. With its central location and easy accessibility, the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki is an ideal destination for anyone seeking a cultural and architectural experience in Greece.
reference: The Aristotle University of Thessaloniki holds architectural significance as the first university campus in Greece built following complete architectural plans, featuring a major ensemble of modern architecture designed by leading Greek architects.

Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '70

(ground floor, room 5). Eight

response:
The Thessaloniki History Centre holds great historical significance in relation to the city's past, particularly its association with the founder of the modern Turkish state, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk. The centre is dedicated to his life and legacy, offering visitors a glimpse into the city's connection to the founder of the Republic of Turkey. 

Located in the historic centre, the museum provides an in-depth look at Atatürk's life, from his early years to his later years as the leader of the Turkish Republic. The museum's collection includes various artifacts, documents, and personal belongings of Atatürk, offering a unique perspective on his life and legacy. 

The Thessaloniki History Centre is also a testament to the city's rich history and its role in the region's cultural and political landscape. As the city's capital during the Ottoman Empire, Thessaloniki played a significant role in the city's development, and the museum serves as a reminder of its importance. 

For a solo traveler looking for a budget-friendly accommodation option, the Thessaloniki History Centre is an excellent choice. With its affordable prices and convenient location, it is an ideal spot for those seeking to experience the city's history and culture. 

Additionally, the Thessaloniki History Centre is an excellent spot for Instagrammable photos. The museum's unique architecture and exhibits make for great social media content, allowing visitors to share their experiences and memories with friends and family. 

Overall, the Thessaloniki History Centre is an excellent choice for those seeking to experience the city's rich history and culture. Its unique exhibits, affordable prices, and convenient location make it an ideal spot for solo travelers, history buffs, and culture enthusiasts alike. 

In terms of accessibility, the Thessaloniki History Centre is easily accessible by public transportation, with multiple bus routes connecting it to the city centre. The museum is also wheelchair accessible, making it a great option for visitors with mobility issues. 

Overall, the Thessaloniki History Centre is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and the city's rich heritage. Its unique exhibits, affordable prices, and convenient location make it an ideal spot for solo travelers and history enthusiasts alike.
reference: The Thessaloniki History Centre holds historical significance as it is situated in a location that was once the center of social activity for citizens until 390 AD, when a massacre ordered by Emperor Theodosius led to the close-down of the Hippodrome.

Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to

This school played a crucial role in shaping the town's education system and served as a hub for intellectual and cultural development. The school's establishment marked a new era of education in Thessaloniki, and it has been a driving force behind the town's growth and progress.

The 1st High School is also notable for being a center of learning for the local community, providing opportunities for young Greeks to receive a quality education. The school's legacy can still be seen today, with its historic buildings and architecture serving as a testament to its enduring impact on the town.

Furthermore, the 1st High School has been a part of the town's cultural heritage for over a century, with its history and traditions deeply intertwined with the local community. The school's significance extends beyond its academic achievements, as it has also played a vital role in promoting the town's values and ideals.

In recent years, the 1st High School has undergone significant renovations and restorations, ensuring that its historic buildings and facilities remain intact and continue to serve as a hub for intellectual and cultural development. Today, the school remains a vital part of Thessaloniki's educational landscape, providing a high-quality education to students of all ages.

Overall, the 1st High School is a symbol of Thessaloniki's rich history and cultural heritage, and its significance extends far beyond its academic achievements. It continues to play a vital role in shaping the town's future, and its legacy will be remembered for generations to come.

The website offers detailed descriptions of the site's layout, its historical significance, and its current state.

Some of the key attractions mentioned on the website include the Sanctuary of Zeus, the Temple of Demeter, and the Vafyras sacred springs. The website also provides information on the site's history, including its construction and the events that led to its decline. 

The website also offers information on how to plan a visit to the site, including opening hours, ticket prices, and directions. Additionally, it provides information on the site's cultural significance, including its importance in the context of ancient Greek mythology and its role in the development of Western civilization.

Visitors to the site can expect to see many impressive structures, including the Great Thermae, the Sanctuary of Demeter, and the remains of the ancient city's infrastructure. The website also mentions the site's connection to the Thermaic Gulf, which was an important source of water for the ancient city.

Overall, the website www.ancientdion.org provides a wealth of information on the archaeological site of Dion, making it an invaluable resource for anyone interested in history, archaeology, or ancient Greek culture. 

Some Instagrammable spots at the site include the Vafyras sacred springs, the Sanctuary of Zeus, and the Great Thermae. Visitors can also expect to see many ancient artifacts and relics, including sculptures, pottery, and other archaeological finds.

This typical downtown

in the early 20th century. This

which has become a leisure 
hub with cafés, bars and 
restaurants inside.
1.2  Hamza Bey Mosque.
It was built in 1467 by the 
daughter of Hamza Bey, the 
military commander of Sultan 
Murad II.', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also

(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern

area is one of the

THESSALONIKI', '42
Thessaloniki’s Old Town is 
full of atmosphere. It covers 
the area in between the city 
walls (to the north and east) 
and Olympiados Street (to 
the south), and has had the 
luck to remain untouched by 
the 1917 great fire. It was 
virtually uninhabited until 
the mid-15th century, when 
it was conquered by the 
Ottomans who selected it for 
settlement on account of its 
fine climate, panoramic views 
and strategic position. The 
two and three-storey houses 
bear mixed Macedonian 
and Ottoman architectural 
elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş 
in turkish]; there are also 
residences with neoclassical 
and eclectic style motifs 
where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. 
converts to Islam who secretly 
remained Jews. After 1922 
many refugees settled in the 
area. Despite the construction 
of newer buildings and the 
opening up of new streets in 
recent decades, it has kept 
its original town planning, to 
a large extent, with narrow 
alleys and scant squares, as 
well as its original architectural 
features, particularly in the 
west and east part of the town. 
This particular atmosphere has 
lured intellects, artists 
and students who chose it  
for settlement in recent years.
1
	 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI 
[SAINT CATHERINE] 
CHURCH
(see p.', '43
5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
2 	TSINARI
This area was named after 
the plane tree which was 
planted there in the early 20th 
c. (çınar is turkish for plane 
tree). You can reach it through 
Al. Papadopoulou Street, one 
of Ano Poli’s hallmark areas 
as are Tsamadou, Sachtouri 
and Isminis Streets. In Isminis 
Street you will find the House

3 	TERPSITHEA SQUARE
Take a good look at the 
remarkable listed buildings and 
the more recent ones as you 
walk along Pileos Street and 
head for Terpsithea Square. 
The buildings surrounding 
the square are amazing and 
offer a wonderful view of the 
town and the seafront; in the 
centre there is a playground 
and a small open-air theatre. 
Another impressive monument 
is the Tϋrbe (Tomb) of Musha  
Baba (1543), one of the late  
ottoman monuments  
of Thessaloniki, shaped

pointed frames on windows 
and a once lead-covered dome.']

various names; in the 19th 
c. it was called Tower of the 
Janissaries or Blood Tower

prisoners on death row 
whose life was eventually 
taken by the Janissaries on 
the ramparts. In 1890 it was 
painted white thus acquiring 
its current name. A particularly 
interesting exhibition is held

of Thessaloniki (see p. 73);

you can enjoy the panoramic 
view. The small square around

hotspots in town; this is where

Opposite lies the Park of the

find the open air Municipal 
Garden Theatre,  
a bar, a playground and  
a skate spot.
1.2  Royal [Vasiliko] 
Theatre.
It was built in 1940, got 
renovated in 1996, and it has 
a seating capacity of 800. 
This is one of the winter halls 
(Melina Merkouri Hall) of the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G., see p. 110). 
1.3  Ethnikis Amynis 
Street.
It leads from the White 
Tower to Syntrivaniou Square 
(see p. 37) and to Agiou 
Dimitriou Street (see p. 39). 
It was laid out after the 1889 
demolition of the eastern 
city walls (a section of its 
Byzantine ramparts still stands 
on Filikis Etaireias Street which 
runs parallel to Ethnikis Amynis 
Street. Until 1912 it was called 
Hamidiye Boulevard, in honour 
of the Sultan Abdul Hamid 
II, as all the buildings along 
the street were his property. 
Today, this is the location of 
the Theatre of the Society for 
Macedonian Studies (1962, 
V. Kassandras) housing the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G.) as well as  
the Gallery of the S.M.S. (see p. 
77), and the adjacent Building 
A’ of the S.M.S. (1951, A. 
Nikolopoulos), the Hellenic 
Army Club (1953, P. Mylonas) 
and Alexandros cinema. The 
small Tsirogiannis Park is 
situated nearby and around 
it you will find some popular 
cafés and bars. 
1.4  Diagonios.
This typical downtown 
22
']
response:
Ethnikis Amynis Street holds significant historical importance in the development of Thessaloniki. The street was originally named Hamidiye Boulevard, in honor of Sultan Abdul Hamid II, and was a major thoroughfare in the city. After the 1889 demolition of the eastern city walls, the street was laid out and became a hub for various buildings, including the Theatre of the Society for Macedonian Studies, the State Theatre of Northern Greece, and the Gallery of the S.M.S.

The street's history is closely tied to the city's multicultural heritage, reflecting its association with great empires, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman Rule. The numerous monuments along the street, dating from various historical periods, showcase Thessaloniki's rich and diverse history. The street's layout and architecture also demonstrate the city's unique blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements.

Today, Ethnikis Amynis Street continues to be a vibrant and bustling area, offering a glimpse into Thessaloniki's fascinating past. Visitors can explore the street's many landmarks, including the White Tower, the House of Pontian Greeks, and the Tsirogiannis Park, which is situated nearby. The street's atmosphere is characterized by its narrow alleys and quaint squares, providing a charming and immersive experience for those who explore it.

As a solo traveler, you'll appreciate the street's accessibility and the variety of shops, cafes, and restaurants that line it. With its rich history and cultural significance, Ethnikis Amynis Street is an absolute must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's heritage. Be sure to capture the street's Instagram-worthy moments, from the picturesque alleys to the stunning architecture, and don't hesitate to interact with the locals, who will be happy to share their knowledge and insights about this iconic street.
reference: Ethnikis Amynis Street holds historical significance as it was laid out after the 1889 demolition of the eastern city walls and was previously known as Hamidiye Boulevard until 1912, reflecting its connection to Sultan Abdul Hamid II and the properties along the street.

ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
Gialourou and Erasmou Streets. 
Eptapyrgio was built in the 12th 
c., presumably on an older 9th c. 
fortress and took this name as 
at first there were seven towers 
there. The current structure 
includes ten towers and a small 
street that goes around it. The 
north side used to be a part  
of the city’s Early Christian 
walls, whereas the towers  
on the south side were added 
during the Byzantine period. In 
1431, the Ottoman Turks made 
certain modifications to them, 
according to an inscription 
placed above the entrance. 
Circa 1890 the construction 
was changed in order to house  
long-term convicts and newer 
buildings were added on 
the inside as well as on the 
outside area. In 1989, the 
prison, known by its Turkish 
name – Yedi Kule, was housed 
elsewhere and the fortress 
became a monument open to 
visitors. It is well worth crossing 
the ring dirt road of the fortress 
where an early Christian cistern 
remains as well as parts of  
an early Christian basilica -  
the spot affords a lovely view!
11 	PALAIOLOGINA’S GATE

Kalochori is situated near the

Gallikos River.

Kalochori lagoon with herons,

towards the west (beyond the

by the rivers Axios, Loudias 
and Aliakmonas. This is a 320 
km2 area, protected by the

2 	KALAMARIA

a self-contained shopping

Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee

The style is neoclassical 
with renaissance features 
and originally it was a three-

It is located in Gefyra village,

of J. Modiano (1906, P. 
Arrigoni). This is where the 
Greek army headquarters were 
set up by Constantine, the 
then heir to the Greek throne, 
on October 24-27, 1912; 
the final negotiations with 
the Turks about surrendering 
Thessaloniki took place on that

as photos and paintings with 
similar subjects. The mansion 
grounds are decorated with

1.2  Giannitsa.
This modern town has a 
population of 35,000 and lies 
10 km W of Ancient Pella. 
The place used to be a sacred 
town for the Muslims since 
this is the burial place of Gazi 
Evrenos [Gazi Evren Bey], one 
of the major Ottoman army 
commanders, as well as of 
Seyh Abdullah al Ilahi, his 
teacher and spiritual father. 
Some of the greatest ottoman 
monuments in Greece are  
to be found in Giannitsa. 
Visit the mausoleum of Gazi 
Evrenos (1417, reconstructed 
in the 19th c.']

response:
The Ottoman stronghold in Angelochori is known as Eptapyrgio, which was built in the 12th century. Initially, it had seven towers, but later additions expanded it to ten. The structure has undergone significant changes over the years, including modifications by the Ottoman Turks in 1431 and later conversions to house long-term convicts. In 1989, the fortress was repurposed as a monument, and today it is open to visitors. 

Upon visiting Eptapyrgio, you can observe several architectural features. The stronghold's current structure includes ten towers, which are a testament to its historical significance. The north side of the fortress was part of Thessaloniki's Early Christian walls, while the towers on the south side were added during the Byzantine period. The Ottoman Turks made modifications to the structure in 1431, which can be seen in the inscription placed above the entrance. 

Visitors can also explore the surrounding area, which features an early Christian cistern and parts of an early Christian basilica. The fortress offers a lovely view of the surrounding landscape, making it an ideal spot for Instagram-worthy photos. 

It is worth noting that Eptapyrgio is not only a historical landmark but also a symbol of Thessaloniki's rich cultural heritage. As a monument, it provides a glimpse into the city's complex history, from the Early Christian period to the Ottoman era. By visiting Eptapyrgio, solo travelers can gain a deeper understanding of Thessaloniki's history and culture, making it an excellent addition to their itinerary.
reference: The Ottoman stronghold in Angelochori, built in 1884 by German civil engineers, holds historical significance due to its architectural structure, which includes a lighthouse reaching a height of 10.50 m.

response:
The Panagouda Church, also known as the Church of Mikri Panagia, holds significant historical importance in relation to the Turkish Occupation in Thessaloniki. According to the excerpt, the church was erected in 1818 on the site of an older church destroyed by fire in 1789. During the Turkish Occupation, the church was located at the heart of the city's Greek quarters, indicating its importance as a symbol of Greek culture and identity. The church's location and its history during the occupation period are a testament to the resilience and determination of the Greek community in Thessaloniki during that time. 

The church's association with the Monastery of Panagia Gorgoepikoos, which was destroyed by fire in 1789, further highlights its historical significance. The fact that the church was rebuilt on the same site suggests that the Greek community was determined to preserve its cultural heritage and identity despite the challenges posed by the Turkish Occupation. 

The church's current location and its association with the Turkish Occupation also provide insight into the complex history of Thessaloniki during that period. The fact that the church was rebuilt in 1818, during the Greek War of Independence, suggests that the city was a hub of activity and cultural expression during that time. 

In summary, the Panagouda Church holds significant historical importance in relation to the Turkish Occupation in Thessaloniki, serving as a symbol of Greek culture and identity and a testament to the resilience of the Greek community during that period. Its association with the Monastery of Panagia Gorgoepikoos and its current location provide further insight into the complex history of the city. 

The church's current state and its preservation as a cultural landmark are a testament to the efforts of the Greek community to preserve their cultural heritage and identity. As a result, the Panagouda Church remains an important historical site in Thessaloniki, providing a glimpse into the city's complex past and its cultural identity.
reference: Panagouda Church holds historical significance as it was erected on the site of an older church destroyed by fire in 1789, located in the heart of the city's Greek quarters during the Turkish Occupation, and is associated with the Monastery of Panagia Gorgoepikoos.

proclaimed a historic area with 
listed buildings. Since the early 
1990s, steps were taken to 
upgrade Ladadika, turning it 
into a hotspot area in town 
with numerous restaurants, 
clubs, cafés and venues where 
live Greek music is performed. 
A central spot where you can 
start your tour is Morichovou 
sq.; it is worth stopping by 
Petrakaki sq. where you will see 
the Mansion of the Ottoman 
Post Office (today a hotel) 
–among other sights. Other 
places of interest are Aigyptou, 
Katouni, Lykourgou, and Edessis 
streets (in Emporiou sq. or 
Ano Ladadika, past Tsimiski 
street) where you will see two 
surviving inns. There are still 
traces of smoke dating to 
the 1917 fire on the facades 
of buildings fronting on the 
harbour!
6 	TSIMISKI STREET
This main street is among the 
busiest downtown places and 
connects YMCA square (see 
p. 26) with Ladadika.']

TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
Construction for the first 
wharf of the port began in 
the late 19th c.; in 1910 six 
warehouses were built and 
all of them are fine examples 
of industrial architecture of 
that time. In 1997, on the 
occasion of events celebrating 
Thessaloniki as the European 
Capital of Culture, five of them 
were revamped and reopened: 
warehouses 1 and D housed 
the International Film Festival 
of Thessaloniki (see p.

Contemporary Art (see p. 75); 
and warehouse C is now  
a bar-restaurant. This place  
is among the most popular 
ones for strolling, relaxing,  
and enjoying a fine view  
of the seafront.

4.1  Customs House 
(Passenger Board).
This imposing 200 m. long 
building was built in 1910, 
designed by architect Eli 
Modiano, and its structure 
bears the influence of early 
20th c. french architecture.  
Since 1987 it is the city port’s

5 	LADADIKA

Street it is worth noticing the

such as Luxemburg Hotel as

Hotels at the junction with 
Mitropoleos streets.
4 	PORT
The area is one of the biggest 
ports of the country and of the 
southeastern Mediterranean, 
with a significant trade and 
passenger traffic. This is where 
the first artificial harbour of 
the town was constructed by 
Constantine the Great during 
his short stay in Thessaloniki 
(322-323 AD); later on during 
the Turkish Occupation it 
was banked up with earth.

aisled post-byzantine basilica.

6.3  The Jewish Museum 
of Thessaloniki.
It is housed in a 1904 historic

owned by Jews. There used to

A very busy street linking

3 	ELEFTHERIAS SQUARE
The square is close to the

open-air car parking lot. This 
is the spot where, back in

forces mustered about 50,000 
Jewish residents in order to 
ship them to concentration

Memorial of the Jewish Greeks

1997 at the square’s northeast

response:
The Customs House, built in 1910, showcases early 20th-century French architecture. Its structure is characterized by long, rectangular shapes and a prominent façade. The building's design is reminiscent of French art nouveau and neoclassical styles, which were popular during that period. The imposing structure bears the influence of French architecture, particularly in its use of symmetrical facades and ornate details. The building's imposing size, measuring 200 meters in length, also contributes to its neoclassical and French art nouveau influences. The Customs House's design reflects the cultural exchange and architectural influences that Thessaloniki experienced during the early 20th century. 

In particular, the building's façade is adorned with ornate details, such as columns and arches, which are typical of French architecture. The use of stone and brick materials also reflects the French influence. The overall design of the Customs House is a testament to the cultural exchange between Greece and France during the early 20th century. The building's architectural style is a blend of French neoclassicism and early 20th-century Greek architecture, making it a unique and fascinating example of cultural exchange in Thessaloniki. 

The building's design has been preserved over the years, and its imposing structure continues to serve as a prominent landmark in the city. Visitors can appreciate the building's French architectural influences when they view it from the outside. The Customs House is an excellent example of Thessaloniki's cultural heritage and a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's history and architecture.
reference: The Customs House, designed by architect Eli Modiano in 1910, shows influences of early 20th century French architecture.

user_input: How do the cultural and historical significances of various sites in Thessaloniki like the International Book Fair, Society for Macedonian Studies, and National Theatre of Northern Greece compare to the culinary traditions and local delicacies that are highlighted in the city's gastronomy?
retrieved_contexts:
['99
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc).', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '\x07Thessaloniki International Trade Fair (HELEXPO)

International Book Fair.  
Held every spring in the 
HELEXPO-TIF exhibition 
centre, it is well known as

for professionals and book

where new books are presented 
and open discussions take

include the honoured country,

Information: National Book 
Centre, 4, Athan. Diakou St,

of Macedonia. It has a large

(see p. 76). A variety of events,

-19th c.); and a collection of

Engraving. Retrospective
